channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sunni Cleric Urges Muslims to Help Syria Rebels
item.description: Sheik Yusef al-Qaradawi, an Egyptian based in Qatar, has been called an extremist by Syrian authorities but has been influential in the uprising.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Hassan Nasrallah has committed Hezbollah to fight on behalf of Syria’s government.

item.title: Mauritania Says U.S. Sent Prisoner From Afghan Base
item.description: The prisoner, Younis al-Mauritani, suspected of being a senior member of Al Qaeda, was transferred from the American military base in Bagram to Mauritania, officials in Mauritania said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sunni-Shiite Violence Flares in Mideast in Wake of Syria War
item.description: The war is setting off a contagious sectarian conflict in Iraq and Lebanon, rekindling long-simmering tensions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, ANNE BARNARD and DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: Iraqi Shiites at the shrine of Sayida Zeinab in Damascus, where the Prophet Muhammad’s granddaughter is said to be buried.

item.title: Police Retreat in Istanbul as Protests Expand Through Turkey
item.description: The police pulled out of Istanbul’s Taksim Square, sparking jubilation and destruction as protests continued against the government’s plan to redevelop a park.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: An officer near Taksim Square in Istanbul, where the unrest expanded in its second day.

item.title: Russian Forces Detain Mayor In Dagestan
item.description: Said D. Amirov, the mayor of Dagestan’s capital, was detained in connection with the 2011 killing of a senior state investigator.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Gunmen Attack Niger Prison
item.description: The escape attempt by prisoners said to be associated with “terrorist groups” on Saturday took place at the central prison in Niger’s capital, Niamey, and two guards were killed.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Brother’s Search Comes to Grim End in Afghanistan
item.description: The remains of two men were found outside a former American Special Forces base in Afghanistan on Saturday, shortly after two other bodies were found nearby.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By SANGAR RAHIMI and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Dmitry Itskov and the Avatar Quest
item.description: Dmitry Itskov wants us all to live forever, our minds inside avatars. And he is spending a bundle to try to make his colossal dream happen.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID SEGAL
item.media:description: Dmitry Itskov, 32, has a colossal dream: to upload the brain’s contents to avatars.

item.title: U.S. and China to Hold Talks on Hacking
item.description: The United States hopes the dialogue can help set norms and end what it says is a daily barrage of computer break-ins and theft of corporate and government secrets by Chinese hackers.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and MARK LANDLER

item.title: The Lede: Daughter of Michigan Woman Killed in Syria Wants Her Body Returned to U.S.
item.description: Friends and family of Nicole Lynn Mansfield struggle to understand how she became caught in a gun battle with Syrian government forces.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Opinion: China’s Economic Empire
item.description: The biggest threat from Beijing is the aggressive spread of state capitalism.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By HERIBERTO ARAÚJO and JUAN PABLO CARDENAL

item.title: For Chris Crane, a Quest to Block an Immigration Bill
item.description: Chris Crane, a deportation officer who leads the union of immigration enforcement agents, has made it his mission to stop a bipartisan bill to overhaul the immigration system.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:credit: Jim McAuley for The New York Times

item.title: Tokhtakhounov Says Criminal Charges Are Just a Misunderstanding
item.description: American authorities view Alimzhan T. Tokhtakhounov as a leading figure in Russian organized crime. They are mistaken, he says.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and JAMES GLANZ
item.media:credit: Oksana Yushko for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I am not bad, like you think,” says Alimzhan T. Tokhtakhounov. “I am not the Mafia, I am not a bandit.” He faces charges in the United States, but not in Russia.

item.title: Hagel, in Remarks Directed at China, Speaks of Cyberattack Threat
item.description: Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel called on America and its allies to “establish international norms of responsible behavior in cyberspace.”
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, left, greeted his British counterpart, Philip Hammond, before a speech on Saturday.

item.title: Grief and Political Reverberations After British Soldier’s Killing
item.description: The killing of Lee Rigby has shocked Britain as few things have in recent years, with the political reverberations continuing for the government of Prime Minister David Cameron.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: Tributes lined the sidewalk outside the barracks where the soldier Lee Rigby, 25, was killed.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 1
item.description: German population fears; identifying factory fire’s victims; unemployment rises in Euro zone; and deflation may be ending in Japan.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Taslima Akhter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hasibul Islam Reaz, 10, has provided blood for efforts to identify his father, who worked in a factory building that collapsed.

item.title: U.S. Targets Iran’s Petrochemical Industry
item.description: In addition to blacklisting Iranian petrochemical companies for the first time, the Obama administration punished businesses in other countries that help Iran evade oil sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Prosecutors Investigate Spending of Government Funds
item.description: Prosecutors in Georgia are investigating allegations that President Mikheil Saakashvili misused government funds, including more than $11,000 for Botox injections.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: U.S. Olympic Leaders Mending Ties With I.O.C.
item.description: The United States Olympic Committee has made changes to satisfy the International Olympic Committee, bolstering a chance to host the 2024 Summer Games.
item.dc:creator: By MARY PILON

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: A Court Seeks Qaddafi’s Son
item.description: Judges at the International Criminal Court ruled that Libya must hand over Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to the court.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Science and Health: Circumcision Device Approved by World Health Organization
item.description: A nonsurgical circumcision device that relies on a rubber band was approved by the World Health Organization, opening the way for its widespread use in Africa.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Elections Postponed
item.description: Lebanon’s Parliament voted to delay elections, which had been scheduled to take place on June 16, for at least 17 months.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Speeds Up Vote
item.description: Zimbabwe’s highest court ordered that national elections be held before the end of July, speeding up the expected timetable to choose a new Parliament and hold a presidential vote.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: One Obstacle Won’t Budge in Japan’s Fight With Deflation
item.description: The Japanese government has made stemming deflation a priority, but its efforts so far have not affected everyday items, like a can of soda.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Vending machines in Japan have become a stubborn barometer of the country’s struggle against deflation.
